citeinfo.origin: Elliott, John E., Laurie K. Wilson, Charles J. Henny, Suzanne F. Trudeau, Kimberly M. Cheng
citeinfo.title: Assessment of biological effects of chlorinated hydrocarbons in osprey chicks
citeinfo.othercit: Science Information System Project #:5001368 Publication Control #:900

descript.abstract: Ospreys (Pandion haliaetus) were first studied throughout Oregon in 1976 and have become a common nesting species along the lower Columbia and Willamette Rivers. A wide range of toxic chemicals is found in the water and sediments and aquatic biota along these rivers, causing concern for many wildlife species associated with the river. Residues of some organochlorine insecticides (OCs), polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), dioxins and furans are potentially toxic to fish, wildlife and humans. These toxic chemicals accumulate in an organism over time through bioaccumulation. OC molecules become more concentrated in organisms at higher trophic levels of the food web through biomagnification. The species of most concern are either fish or fish-eating wildlife species at the top of the food web. Ospreys have many life history traits making it useful for environmental contaminant reseach: 1) eating and capturing fish within a relatively short distance from their nest sites, 2) long-lived with high nest site fidelity, 3) nests easily detected during surveys, 4) often nests on man-made structures, facilitating nest access, 5) tolerates short-term nest site disturbance, 6) removal of sample egg has minimal effect on local population, and 7) species reproduction adversely impacted by DDE-induced eggshell thinning and effects of chlorinated hydrocarbon and mercury pollutants. An Osprey egg provides a snapshot of the toxic contaminants present in the adult female’s body at the time the egg was formed. Therefore, we initiated studies along the Willamette and the Columbia River to evaluate contaminants in Osprey eggs and prey and to determine if Osprey could be used as an indicator or sentinel species for long-term monitoring of contaminant loading and the general health of the rivers.
